Name: Temporal-Meeting Pattern Analyzer
Purpose: Derive a formal model of current meeting patterns across time zones, including recurrence, duration, participant overlap, and sync/async substitution potential, to expose where synchronous time is concentrated and constrained.
Deliverables: A time-segmented schedule model: (1) a normalized calendar grid by time zone and role; (2) a set of meeting-classes (status, decision, planning, social, 1:1, cross-team) with rules describing typical timing, duration, and attendance; (3) exception rules for irregular or ad-hoc meetings; (4) a classification of meetings by necessity-of-synchronicity (hard-sync, soft-sync, potentially-async) based solely on structural features (inputs, outputs, required participants, dependencies).
Strengths: Good at revealing clusters of meeting load, identifying participants or roles with fragmented focus time, and locating structurally redundant or overlapping meetings; can systematically flag where synchronous time is used for information broadcast or uncontroversial updates that structurally fit async patterns; supports quantification of meeting fatigue from a temporal/structural perspective.
Watch-out: Breaks when calendar data is noisy (incorrect titles, missing attendees, misused recurring events) or when meeting purpose is only informally known; cannot account for interpersonal dynamics, psychological safety, or perceived value of meetings; must not provide time-management coaching, facilitation advice, or propose new cadences; must not reason about performance, engagement, or moraleâ€”only about the structure and classification of existing meetings in time.
